Hi all, 

I was thinking of how to characterize behavior of an agent in a 
=
complex dynamic world. As you all know, the 2D maze world in the 
demos is =
a static one. It doesn't interact with the agent. Thus it is 
possible for =
Novelty Search to exploit the static environment and 
develop behaviors tha=
t are not successful or meaningful on even 
slightly different maze configu=
rations. I don't say that NS doesn't 
find general solutions able to naviga=
te most mazes. I mean that "born 
to solve only this particular maze" solut=
ions appear often. 

Further, what if I add more agents, in a realtime inte=
ravtive 
environment like the one in NERO? While trying to generalize 
ever=
ything I see in terms of behavior characterization, it was 
difficult to ju=
st say "the agent does this!" and use it as BC. It is 
because the real wor=
ld environment is not static, it interacts with 
the agent, so it becomes s=
omething like noisy evaluation when I try 
to evolve one. The same individu=
al could appear more and less novel 
every time. 

So one day, I was observ=
ing my dog.. Let's think of my dog as a 
complex biological agent in a real=
 world interactive environment.. If 
you try to make a summary of its behav=
ior, how can you do it? One may 
suggest to put the dog in various situatio=
ns and observe its 
reactions, finally collecting a summary of what it does=
 in those 
situations. While this seems like the solution, it is not. Becau=
se in 
order to compare different dogs, you will have to put all of them 
t=
hrough the same tests in order to avoid the noisy evaluation. And 
this bri=
ngs us to a static environment again, because we know what 
exactly is goin=
g to happen to all agents, in order to see their 
reactions. While realizin=
g that, I arrived on a better idea that I am 
going to talk about now. 

In=
 a complex interactive world, a little is known what exactly can 
happen to=
 an agent. Further, the agent has a limited set of actions 
that it can tak=
e. A behavior characterization taking into account the 
actions only is not=
 enough, because it is not known what happened to 
the agent before that ac=
tion. So one solution I came up with is this 
one. You have a list of all p=
ossible and/or performed actions for the 
BC. For each action, a summary or=
 a more detailed list of situations 
must exist. So basically let's say tha=
t we have a simple robot that 
can go forward, fire a rocket and turn left/=
right. With rangefinger 
sensors or whatever. Instead of tracking only *wha=
t* it did during 
its lifetime, the system now has to track also in what ci=
rcumstances 
the particular action took place, and add that to the summary =
of 
behavior. This can be the inputs at that particular timestep, for 
exam=
ple. Or the relative positions of other agents that it may 
interact with. =


Does it make sense? Suppose you try to characterize a driver in a 
city t=
raffic conditions. Anything can happen. But if you also track 
what the dri=
ver *sees* in the particular moments when he acts, in 
addition to what act=
ions he takes, it is a lot easier to distinguish 
between different driving=
 behaviors.

I will be happy to hear your thoughts about this. Perhaps it i=
s 
nothing new, but I didn't see any discussion about it. Though it is 
an =
important issue about how to use Novelty Search for multi-agent, 
coevoluti=
onary, and some real-world applicatons. 

Peter
